parts.text:
Spack

```json
{
  "application": "Spack",
  "software": "PETSc 3.16.1",
  "compiler": "Intel 19.1.1.217",
  "scheduler": "Slurm",
  "resources": {
    "nodes": 1,
    "tasks_per_node": 1,
    "cpus_per_task": 16,
    "memory": "32G",
    "time": "00:30:00"
  },
  "dependencies": [
    "python@3.8.12",
    "openblas@0.3.17",
    "hdf5@1.10.7",
    "parmetis@4.0.3",
    "intel-mpi@2019.10.317"
  ],
  "variants": [
    "~X",
    "~batch",
    "~cgns",
    "~complex",
    "~cuda",
    "~debug",
    "+double",
    "~exodusii",
    "~fftw",
    "~giflib",
    "+hdf5",
    "~hpddm",
    "~hwloc",
    "~hypre",
    "~int64",
    "~jpeg",
    "~knl",
    "~libpng",
    "~libyaml",
    "~memkind",
    "+metis",
    "~mkl-pardiso",
    "~mmg",
    "~moab",
    "~mpfr",
    "+mpi",
    "~mumps",
    "~p4est",
    "~parmmg",
    "+ptscotch",
    "~random123",
    "~rocm",
    "~saws",
    "~scalapack",
    "+shared",
    "~strumpack",
    "~suite-sparse",
    "~superlu-dist",
    "~tetgen",
    "~trilinos",
    "~valgrind"
  ]
}
``` 

This script uses Spack, a package manager for scientific software. It sets up a specific version of PETSc (3.16.1) with Intel compiler and a set of variants.

The script then uses Slurm, a workload manager, to run the Spack installation and configure the environment for PETSc. It specifies the resources needed for the job, including number of nodes, tasks per node, CPUs per task, memory, and wall-time.

The script includes dependencies for PETSc, including Python, OpenBLAS, HDF5, and ParMETIS.

Finally, the script launches a script for a PETSc complex (cmplx) test after the PETSc installation is complete, again using Slurm.
